item.title: In Retirement, a Champion Is a Crusader for the Game
item.description: When he isn’t advocating for political change in Russia, Garry Kasparov is leading a campaign to include chess classes in schools around the world.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Robert Byrne, Chess Grandmaster, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Byrne analyzed top-flight matches and wrote a chess column for The New York Times from 1972 to 2006.
item.author: By BRUCE WEBER

item.title: Brooklyn School Takes Title at the ‘Supernationals’
item.description: Edward R. Murrow High School won its division in the scholastic championships last week, and Webster University of St. Louis was the Final Four of College Chess title winner.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Shrewd Marketing Moves for Top-Ranked Chess Player
item.description: Chess has its superstars, but on a wider stage, there is no one like Magnus Carlsen, who uses his intelligence, looks and charm to increase his profile outside of the game, as if he were a tennis or golf star.
item.author: By SARAH LYALL

item.title: No. 1 Player Gets a Chance to Pick Off the World Champ
item.description: Magnus Carlsen eked out a victory in the Candidates Tournament to win the right to challenge Viswanathan Anand for the world championship.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: A Conversation With: Chess Champion Viswanathan Anand
item.description: The chess legend on promoting chess for children across India to improve academic performance.
item.author: By SRIRAM BALASUBRAMANIAN

item.title: 9-Year-Old Breaks Record for Youngest U.S. Master
item.description: Awonder Liang broke the record set in 2010 by Samuel Sevian of California, who was 10 days older when he achieved the master rank.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Change in Title Format Forces Switch in Strategies
item.description: The World Chess Federation is using a tournament this year to choose a challenger to the world champion, Viswanathan Anand, and the players vying for that chance have had to adapt.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Ukraine Wins Women’s Event Skipped by Many Big Names
item.description: The notable absence of some of chess’s elite players may have helped Ukraine grab the title at this year’s Women’s World Team Championship.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Grandmaster Draws Persist, but So Do Fights to the End
item.description: Intentional draws to maintain a share of the prize are a scourge of tournaments, but others must compete for first.
item.author: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN
